2127    ///     .arg(Arg::new("bar"))
2128    ///     .arg(Arg::new("baz").action(ArgAction::Set).num_args(1..))
2129    ///     .get_matches_from(vec![
2130    ///         "prog", "foo", "bar", "baz1", "baz2", "baz3"
2131    ///     ]);
2132    ///
2133    /// assert_eq!(m.get_one::<String>("foo").unwrap(), "foo");
2134    /// assert_eq!(m.get_one::<String>("bar").unwrap(), "bar");
2135    /// assert_eq!(m.get_many::<String>("baz").unwrap().collect::<Vec<_>>(), &["baz1", "baz2", "baz3"]);
2136    /// ```
2137    ///
2138    /// Now nofice if we don't specify `foo` or `baz` but use the `--` operator.
2139    ///
2140    /// ```rust
2141    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, ArgAction};
2142    /// // Assume there is an external subcommand named "subcmd"
2143    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2144    ///     .allow_missing_positional(true)
2145    ///     .arg(Arg::new("foo"))
2146    ///     .arg(Arg::new("bar"))
2147    ///     .arg(Arg::new("baz").action(ArgAction::Set).num_args(1..))
2148    ///     .get_matches_from(vec![
2149    ///         "prog", "--", "baz1", "baz2", "baz3"
2150    ///     ]);
2151    ///
2152    /// assert_eq!(m.get_one::<String>("foo"), None);
2153    /// assert_eq!(m.get_one::<String>("bar"), None);
2154    /// assert_eq!(m.get_many::<String>("baz").unwrap().collect::<Vec<_>>(), &["baz1", "baz2", "baz3"]);
2155    /// ```
2156    ///
2157    /// [required]: crate::Arg::required()
2158    #[inline]
2159    pub fn allow_missing_positional(self, yes: bool) -> Self {
2160        if yes {
2161            self.setting(AppSettings::AllowMissingPositional)
2162        } else {
2163            self.unset_setting(AppSettings::AllowMissingPositional)
2164        }
2165    }
2166}
2167
2168/// # Subcommand-specific Settings
2169impl Command {
2170    /// Sets the short version of the subcommand flag without the preceding `-`.
2171    ///
2172    /// Allows the subcommand to be used as if it were an [`Arg::short`].
2173    ///
2174    /// # Examples
2175    ///
2176    /// ```
2177    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, ArgAction};
2178    /// let matches = Command::new("pacman")
2179    ///     .subcommand(
2180    ///         Command::new("sync").short_flag('S').arg(
2181    ///             Arg::new("search")
2182    ///                 .short('s')
2183    ///                 .long("search")
2184    ///                 .action(ArgAction::SetTrue)
2185    ///                 .help("search remote repositories for matching strings"),
2186    ///         ),
2187    ///     )
2188    ///     .get_matches_from(vec!["pacman", "-Ss"]);
2189    ///
2190    /// assert_eq!(matches.subcommand_name().unwrap(), "sync");
2191    /// let sync_matches = matches.subcommand_matches("sync").unwrap();
2192    /// assert!(*sync_matches.get_one::<bool>("search").expect("defaulted by clap"));
2193    /// ```
2194    /// [`Arg::short`]: Arg::short()
2195    #[must_use]
2196    pub fn short_flag(mut self, short: impl IntoResettable<char>) -> Self {
2197        self.short_flag = short.into_resettable().into_option();
2198        self
2199    }
2200
2201    /// Sets the long version of the subcommand flag without the preceding `--`.
2202    ///
2203    /// Allows the subcommand to be used as if it were an [`Arg::long`].
2204    ///
2205    /// **NOTE:** Any leading `-` characters will be stripped.
2206    ///
2207    /// # Examples
2208    ///
2209    /// To set `long_flag` use a word containing valid UTF-8 codepoints. If you supply a double leading
2210    /// `--` such as `--sync` they will be stripped. Hyphens in the middle of the word; however,
2211    /// will *not* be stripped (i.e. `sync-file` is allowed).
2212    ///
2213    /// ```
2214    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, ArgAction};
2215    /// let matches = Command::new("pacman")
2216    ///     .subcommand(
2217    ///         Command::new("sync").long_flag("sync").arg(
2218    ///             Arg::new("search")
2219    ///                 .short('s')
2220    ///                 .long("search")
2221    ///                 .action(ArgAction::SetTrue)
2222    ///                 .help("search remote repositories for matching strings"),
2223    ///         ),
2224    ///     )
2225    ///     .get_matches_from(vec!["pacman", "--sync", "--search"]);
2226    ///
2227    /// assert_eq!(matches.subcommand_name().unwrap(), "sync");
2228    /// let sync_matches = matches.subcommand_matches("sync").unwrap();
2229    /// assert!(*sync_matches.get_one::<bool>("search").expect("defaulted by clap"));
2230    /// ```
2231    ///
2232    /// [`Arg::long`]: Arg::long()
2233    #[must_use]
2234    pub fn long_flag(mut self, long: impl Into<Str>) -> Self {
2235        self.long_flag = Some(long.into());
2236        self
2237    }
2238
2239    /// Sets a hidden alias to this subcommand.
2240    ///
2241    /// This allows the subcommand to be accessed via *either* the original name, or this given
2242    /// alias. This is more efficient and easier than creating multiple hidden subcommands as one
2243    /// only needs to check for the existence of this command, and not all aliased variants.
2244    ///
2245    /// **NOTE:** Aliases defined with this method are *hidden* from the help
2246    /// message. If you're looking for aliases that will be displayed in the help
2247    /// message, see [`Command::visible_alias`].
2248    ///
2249    /// **NOTE:** When using aliases and checking for the existence of a
2250    /// particular subcommand within an [`ArgMatches`] struct, one only needs to
2251    /// search for the original name and not all aliases.
2252    ///
2253    /// # Examples
2254    ///
2255    /// ```rust
2256    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2257    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2258    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("test")
2259    ///         .alias("do-stuff"))
2260    ///     .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "do-stuff"]);
2261    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2262    /// ```
2263    /// [`Command::visible_alias`]: Command::visible_alias()
2264    #[must_use]
2265    pub fn alias(mut self, name: impl IntoResettable<Str>) -> Self {
2266        if let Some(name) = name.into_resettable().into_option() {
2267            self.aliases.push((name, false));
2268        } else {
2269            self.aliases.clear();
2270        }
2271        self
2272    }
2273
2274    /// Add an alias, which functions as  "hidden" short flag subcommand
2275    ///
2276    /// This will automatically dispatch as if this subcommand was used. This is more efficient,
2277    /// and easier than creating multiple hidden subcommands as one only needs to check for the
2278    /// existence of this command, and not all variants.
2279    ///
2280    /// # Examples
2281    ///
2282    /// ```no_run
2283    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2284    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2285    ///             .subcommand(Command::new("test").short_flag('t')
2286    ///                 .short_flag_alias('d'))
2287    ///             .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "-d"]);
2288    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2289    /// ```
2290    #[must_use]
2291    pub fn short_flag_alias(mut self, name: impl IntoResettable<char>) -> Self {
2292        if let Some(name) = name.into_resettable().into_option() {
2293            debug_assert!(name != '-', "short alias name cannot be `-`");
2294            self.short_flag_aliases.push((name, false));
2295        } else {
2296            self.short_flag_aliases.clear();
2297        }
2298        self
2299    }
2300
2301    /// Add an alias, which functions as a "hidden" long flag subcommand.
2302    ///
2303    /// This will automatically dispatch as if this subcommand was used. This is more efficient,
2304    /// and easier than creating multiple hidden subcommands as one only needs to check for the
2305    /// existence of this command, and not all variants.
2306    ///
2307    /// # Examples
2308    ///
2309    /// ```no_run
2310    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2311    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2312    ///             .subcommand(Command::new("test").long_flag("test")
2313    ///                 .long_flag_alias("testing"))
2314    ///             .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "--testing"]);
2315    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2316    /// ```
2317    #[must_use]
2318    pub fn long_flag_alias(mut self, name: impl IntoResettable<Str>) -> Self {
2319        if let Some(name) = name.into_resettable().into_option() {
2320            self.long_flag_aliases.push((name, false));
2321        } else {
2322            self.long_flag_aliases.clear();
2323        }
2324        self
2325    }
2326
2327    /// Sets multiple hidden aliases to this subcommand.
2328    ///
2329    /// This allows the subcommand to be accessed via *either* the original name or any of the
2330    /// given aliases. This is more efficient, and easier than creating multiple hidden subcommands
2331    /// as one only needs to check for the existence of this command and not all aliased variants.
2332    ///
2333    /// **NOTE:** Aliases defined with this method are *hidden* from the help
2334    /// message. If looking for aliases that will be displayed in the help
2335    /// message, see [`Command::visible_aliases`].
2336    ///
2337    /// **NOTE:** When using aliases and checking for the existence of a
2338    /// particular subcommand within an [`ArgMatches`] struct, one only needs to
2339    /// search for the original name and not all aliases.
2340    ///
2341    /// # Examples
2342    ///
2343    /// ```rust
2344    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg};
2345    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2346    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("test")
2347    ///         .aliases(["do-stuff", "do-tests", "tests"]))
2348    ///         .arg(Arg::new("input")
2349    ///             .help("the file to add")
2350    ///             .required(false))
2351    ///     .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "do-tests"]);
2352    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2353    /// ```
2354    /// [`Command::visible_aliases`]: Command::visible_aliases()
2355    #[must_use]
2356    pub fn aliases(mut self, names: impl IntoIterator<Item = impl Into<Str>>) -> Self {
2357        self.aliases
2358            .extend(names.into_iter().map(|n| (n.into(), false)));
2359        self
2360    }
2361
2362    /// Add aliases, which function as "hidden" short flag subcommands.
2363    ///
2364    /// These will automatically dispatch as if this subcommand was used. This is more efficient,
2365    /// and easier than creating multiple hidden subcommands as one only needs to check for the
2366    /// existence of this command, and not all variants.
2367    ///
2368    /// # Examples
2369    ///
2370    /// ```rust
2371    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2372    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2373    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("test").short_flag('t')
2374    ///         .short_flag_aliases(['a', 'b', 'c']))
2375    ///         .arg(Arg::new("input")
2376    ///             .help("the file to add")
2377    ///             .required(false))
2378    ///     .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "-a"]);
2379    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2380    /// ```
2381    #[must_use]
2382    pub fn short_flag_aliases(mut self, names: impl IntoIterator<Item = char>) -> Self {
2383        for s in names {
2384            debug_assert!(s != '-', "short alias name cannot be `-`");
2385            self.short_flag_aliases.push((s, false));
2386        }
2387        self
2388    }
2389
2390    /// Add aliases, which function as "hidden" long flag subcommands.
2391    ///
2392    /// These will automatically dispatch as if this subcommand was used. This is more efficient,
2393    /// and easier than creating multiple hidden subcommands as one only needs to check for the
2394    /// existence of this command, and not all variants.
2395    ///
2396    /// # Examples
2397    ///
2398    /// ```rust
2399    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2400    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2401    ///             .subcommand(Command::new("test").long_flag("test")
2402    ///                 .long_flag_aliases(["testing", "testall", "test_all"]))
2403    ///                 .arg(Arg::new("input")
2404    ///                             .help("the file to add")
2405    ///                             .required(false))
2406    ///             .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "--testing"]);
2407    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2408    /// ```
2409    #[must_use]
2410    pub fn long_flag_aliases(mut self, names: impl IntoIterator<Item = impl Into<Str>>) -> Self {
2411        for s in names {
2412            self = self.long_flag_alias(s)
2413        }
2414        self
2415    }
2416
2417    /// Sets a visible alias to this subcommand.
2418    ///
2419    /// This allows the subcommand to be accessed via *either* the
2420    /// original name or the given alias. This is more efficient and easier
2421    /// than creating hidden subcommands as one only needs to check for
2422    /// the existence of this command and not all aliased variants.
2423    ///
2424    /// **NOTE:** The alias defined with this method is *visible* from the help
2425    /// message and displayed as if it were just another regular subcommand. If
2426    /// looking for an alias that will not be displayed in the help message, see
2427    /// [`Command::alias`].
2428    ///
2429    /// **NOTE:** When using aliases and checking for the existence of a
2430    /// particular subcommand within an [`ArgMatches`] struct, one only needs to
2431    /// search for the original name and not all aliases.
2432    ///
2433    /// # Examples
2434    ///
2435    /// ```no_run
2436    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg};
2437    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2438    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("test")
2439    ///         .visible_alias("do-stuff"))
2440    ///     .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "do-stuff"]);
2441    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2442    /// ```
2443    /// [`Command::alias`]: Command::alias()
2444    #[must_use]
2445    pub fn visible_alias(mut self, name: impl IntoResettable<Str>) -> Self {
2446        if let Some(name) = name.into_resettable().into_option() {
2447            self.aliases.push((name, true));
2448        } else {
2449            self.aliases.clear();
2450        }
2451        self
2452    }
2453
2454    /// Add an alias, which functions as  "visible" short flag subcommand
2455    ///
2456    /// This will automatically dispatch as if this subcommand was used. This is more efficient,
2457    /// and easier than creating multiple hidden subcommands as one only needs to check for the
2458    /// existence of this command, and not all variants.
2459    ///
2460    /// See also [`Command::short_flag_alias`].
2461    ///
2462    /// # Examples
2463    ///
2464    /// ```no_run
2465    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2466    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2467    ///             .subcommand(Command::new("test").short_flag('t')
2468    ///                 .visible_short_flag_alias('d'))
2469    ///             .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "-d"]);
2470    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2471    /// ```
2472    /// [`Command::short_flag_alias`]: Command::short_flag_alias()
2473    #[must_use]
2474    pub fn visible_short_flag_alias(mut self, name: impl IntoResettable<char>) -> Self {
2475        if let Some(name) = name.into_resettable().into_option() {
2476            debug_assert!(name != '-', "short alias name cannot be `-`");
2477            self.short_flag_aliases.push((name, true));
2478        } else {
2479            self.short_flag_aliases.clear();
2480        }
2481        self
2482    }
2483
2484    /// Add an alias, which functions as a "visible" long flag subcommand.
2485    ///
2486    /// This will automatically dispatch as if this subcommand was used. This is more efficient,
2487    /// and easier than creating multiple hidden subcommands as one only needs to check for the
2488    /// existence of this command, and not all variants.
2489    ///
2490    /// See also [`Command::long_flag_alias`].
2491    ///
2492    /// # Examples
2493    ///
2494    /// ```no_run
2495    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2496    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2497    ///             .subcommand(Command::new("test").long_flag("test")
2498    ///                 .visible_long_flag_alias("testing"))
2499    ///             .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "--testing"]);
2500    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2501    /// ```
2502    /// [`Command::long_flag_alias`]: Command::long_flag_alias()
2503    #[must_use]
2504    pub fn visible_long_flag_alias(mut self, name: impl IntoResettable<Str>) -> Self {
2505        if let Some(name) = name.into_resettable().into_option() {
2506            self.long_flag_aliases.push((name, true));
2507        } else {
2508            self.long_flag_aliases.clear();
2509        }
2510        self
2511    }
2512
2513    /// Sets multiple visible aliases to this subcommand.
2514    ///
2515    /// This allows the subcommand to be accessed via *either* the
2516    /// original name or any of the given aliases. This is more efficient and easier
2517    /// than creating multiple hidden subcommands as one only needs to check for
2518    /// the existence of this command and not all aliased variants.
2519    ///
2520    /// **NOTE:** The alias defined with this method is *visible* from the help
2521    /// message and displayed as if it were just another regular subcommand. If
2522    /// looking for an alias that will not be displayed in the help message, see
2523    /// [`Command::alias`].
2524    ///
2525    /// **NOTE:** When using aliases, and checking for the existence of a
2526    /// particular subcommand within an [`ArgMatches`] struct, one only needs to
2527    /// search for the original name and not all aliases.
2528    ///
2529    /// # Examples
2530    ///
2531    /// ```no_run
2532    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2533    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2534    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("test")
2535    ///         .visible_aliases(["do-stuff", "tests"]))
2536    ///     .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "do-stuff"]);
2537    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2538    /// ```
2539    /// [`Command::alias`]: Command::alias()
2540    #[must_use]
2541    pub fn visible_aliases(mut self, names: impl IntoIterator<Item = impl Into<Str>>) -> Self {
2542        self.aliases
2543            .extend(names.into_iter().map(|n| (n.into(), true)));
2544        self
2545    }
2546
2547    /// Add aliases, which function as *visible* short flag subcommands.
2548    ///
2549    /// See [`Command::short_flag_aliases`].
2550    ///
2551    /// # Examples
2552    ///
2553    /// ```no_run
2554    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2555    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2556    ///             .subcommand(Command::new("test").short_flag('b')
2557    ///                 .visible_short_flag_aliases(['t']))
2558    ///             .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "-t"]);
2559    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2560    /// ```
2561    /// [`Command::short_flag_aliases`]: Command::short_flag_aliases()
2562    #[must_use]
2563    pub fn visible_short_flag_aliases(mut self, names: impl IntoIterator<Item = char>) -> Self {
2564        for s in names {
2565            debug_assert!(s != '-', "short alias name cannot be `-`");
2566            self.short_flag_aliases.push((s, true));
2567        }
2568        self
2569    }
2570
2571    /// Add aliases, which function as *visible* long flag subcommands.
2572    ///
2573    /// See [`Command::long_flag_aliases`].
2574    ///
2575    /// # Examples
2576    ///
2577    /// ```no_run
2578    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, };
2579    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2580    ///             .subcommand(Command::new("test").long_flag("test")
2581    ///                 .visible_long_flag_aliases(["testing", "testall", "test_all"]))
2582    ///             .get_matches_from(vec!["myprog", "--testing"]);
2583    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("test"));
2584    /// ```
2585    /// [`Command::long_flag_aliases`]: Command::long_flag_aliases()
2586    #[must_use]
2587    pub fn visible_long_flag_aliases(
2588        mut self,
2589        names: impl IntoIterator<Item = impl Into<Str>>,
2590    ) -> Self {
2591        for s in names {
2592            self = self.visible_long_flag_alias(s);
2593        }
2594        self
2595    }
2596
2597    /// Set the placement of this subcommand within the help.
2598    ///
2599    /// Subcommands with a lower value will be displayed first in the help message.  Subcommands
2600    /// with duplicate display orders will be displayed in alphabetical order.
2601    ///
2602    /// This is helpful when one would like to emphasize frequently used subcommands, or prioritize
2603    /// those towards the top of the list.
2604    ///
2605    /// **NOTE:** The default is 999 for all subcommands.
2606    ///
2607    /// # Examples
2608    ///
2609    #[cfg_attr(not(feature = "help"), doc = " ```ignore")]
2610    #[cfg_attr(feature = "help", doc = " ```")]
2611    /// # use clap::{Command, };
2612    /// let m = Command::new("cust-ord")
2613    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("alpha") // typically subcommands are grouped
2614    ///                                                // alphabetically by name. Subcommands
2615    ///                                                // without a display_order have a value of
2616    ///                                                // 999 and are displayed alphabetically with
2617    ///                                                // all other 999 subcommands
2618    ///         .about("Some help and text"))
2619    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("beta")
2620    ///         .display_order(1)   // In order to force this subcommand to appear *first*
2621    ///                             // all we have to do is give it a value lower than 999.
2622    ///                             // Any other subcommands with a value of 1 will be displayed
2623    ///                             // alphabetically with this one...then 2 values, then 3, etc.
2624    ///         .about("I should be first!"))
2625    ///     .get_matches_from(vec![
2626    ///         "cust-ord", "--help"
2627    ///     ]);
2628    /// ```
2629    ///
2630    /// The above example displays the following help message
2631    ///
2632    /// ```text
2633    /// cust-ord
2634    ///
2635    /// Usage: cust-ord [OPTIONS]
2636    ///
2637    /// Commands:
2638    ///     beta    I should be first!
2639    ///     alpha   Some help and text
2640    ///
2641    /// Options:
2642    ///     -h, --help       Print help information
2643    ///     -V, --version    Print version information
2644    /// ```
2645    #[inline]
2646    #[must_use]
2647    pub fn display_order(mut self, ord: impl IntoResettable<usize>) -> Self {
2648        self.disp_ord = ord.into_resettable().into_option();
2649        self
2650    }
2651
2652    /// Specifies that this [`subcommand`] should be hidden from help messages
2653    ///
2654    /// # Examples
2655    ///
2656    /// ```rust
2657    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg};
2658    /// Command::new("myprog")
2659    ///     .subcommand(
2660    ///         Command::new("test").hide(true)
2661    ///     )
2662    /// # ;
2663    /// ```
2664    ///
2665    /// [`subcommand`]: crate::Command::subcommand()
2666    #[inline]
2667    pub fn hide(self, yes: bool) -> Self {
2668        if yes {
2669            self.setting(AppSettings::Hidden)
2670        } else {
2671            self.unset_setting(AppSettings::Hidden)
2672        }
2673    }
2674
2675    /// If no [`subcommand`] is present at runtime, error and exit gracefully.
2676    ///
2677    /// # Examples
2678    ///
2679    /// ```rust
2680    /// # use clap::{Command, error::ErrorKind};
2681    /// let err = Command::new("myprog")
2682    ///     .subcommand_required(true)
2683    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("test"))
2684    ///     .try_get_matches_from(vec![
2685    ///         "myprog",
2686    ///     ]);
2687    /// assert!(err.is_err());
2688    /// assert_eq!(err.unwrap_err().kind(), ErrorKind::MissingSubcommand);
2689    /// # ;
2690    /// ```
2691    ///
2692    /// [`subcommand`]: crate::Command::subcommand()
2693    pub fn subcommand_required(self, yes: bool) -> Self {
2694        if yes {
2695            self.setting(AppSettings::SubcommandRequired)
2696        } else {
2697            self.unset_setting(AppSettings::SubcommandRequired)
2698        }
2699    }
2700
2701    /// Assume unexpected positional arguments are a [`subcommand`].
2702    ///
2703    /// Arguments will be stored in the `""` argument in the [`ArgMatches`]
2704    ///
2705    /// **NOTE:** Use this setting with caution,
2706    /// as a truly unexpected argument (i.e. one that is *NOT* an external subcommand)
2707    /// will **not** cause an error and instead be treated as a potential subcommand.
2708    /// One should check for such cases manually and inform the user appropriately.
2709    ///
2710    /// **NOTE:** A built-in subcommand will be parsed as an external subcommand when escaped with
2711    /// `--`.
2712    ///
2713    /// # Examples
2714    ///
2715    /// ```rust
2716    /// # use std::ffi::OsString;
2717    /// # use clap::Command;
2718    /// // Assume there is an external subcommand named "subcmd"
2719    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2720    ///     .allow_external_subcommands(true)
2721    ///     .get_matches_from(vec![
2722    ///         "myprog", "subcmd", "--option", "value", "-fff", "--flag"
2723    ///     ]);
2724    ///
2725    /// // All trailing arguments will be stored under the subcommand's sub-matches using an empty
2726    /// // string argument name
2727    /// match m.subcommand() {
2728    ///     Some((external, ext_m)) => {
2729    ///          let ext_args: Vec<_> = ext_m.get_many::<OsString>("").unwrap().collect();
2730    ///          assert_eq!(external, "subcmd");
2731    ///          assert_eq!(ext_args, ["--option", "value", "-fff", "--flag"]);
2732    ///     },
2733    ///     _ => {},
2734    /// }
2735    /// ```
2736    ///
2737    /// [`subcommand`]: crate::Command::subcommand()
2738    /// [`ArgMatches`]: crate::ArgMatches
2739    /// [`ErrorKind::UnknownArgument`]: crate::error::ErrorKind::UnknownArgument
2740    pub fn allow_external_subcommands(self, yes: bool) -> Self {
2741        if yes {
2742            self.setting(AppSettings::AllowExternalSubcommands)
2743        } else {
2744            self.unset_setting(AppSettings::AllowExternalSubcommands)
2745        }
2746    }
2747
2748    /// Specifies how to parse external subcommand arguments.
2749    ///
2750    /// The default parser is for `OsString`.  This can be used to switch it to `String` or another
2751    /// type.
2752    ///
2753    /// **NOTE:** Setting this requires [`Command::allow_external_subcommands`]
2754    ///
2755    /// # Examples
2756    ///
2757    #[cfg_attr(not(unix), doc = " ```ignore")]
2758    #[cfg_attr(unix, doc = " ```")]
2759    /// # use std::ffi::OsString;
2760    /// # use clap::Command;
2761    /// # use clap::value_parser;
2762    /// // Assume there is an external subcommand named "subcmd"
2763    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2764    ///     .allow_external_subcommands(true)
2765    ///     .get_matches_from(vec![
2766    ///         "myprog", "subcmd", "--option", "value", "-fff", "--flag"
2767    ///     ]);
2768    ///
2769    /// // All trailing arguments will be stored under the subcommand's sub-matches using an empty
2770    /// // string argument name
2771    /// match m.subcommand() {
2772    ///     Some((external, ext_m)) => {
2773    ///          let ext_args: Vec<_> = ext_m.get_many::<OsString>("").unwrap().collect();
2774    ///          assert_eq!(external, "subcmd");
2775    ///          assert_eq!(ext_args, ["--option", "value", "-fff", "--flag"]);
2776    ///     },
2777    ///     _ => {},
2778    /// }
2779    /// ```
2780    ///
2781    /// ```
2782    /// # use clap::Command;
2783    /// # use clap::value_parser;
2784    /// // Assume there is an external subcommand named "subcmd"
2785    /// let m = Command::new("myprog")
2786    ///     .external_subcommand_value_parser(value_parser!(String))
2787    ///     .get_matches_from(vec![
2788    ///         "myprog", "subcmd", "--option", "value", "-fff", "--flag"
2789    ///     ]);
2790    ///
2791    /// // All trailing arguments will be stored under the subcommand's sub-matches using an empty
2792    /// // string argument name
2793    /// match m.subcommand() {
2794    ///     Some((external, ext_m)) => {
2795    ///          let ext_args: Vec<_> = ext_m.get_many::<String>("").unwrap().collect();
2796    ///          assert_eq!(external, "subcmd");
2797    ///          assert_eq!(ext_args, ["--option", "value", "-fff", "--flag"]);
2798    ///     },
2799    ///     _ => {},
2800    /// }
2801    /// ```
2802    ///
2803    /// [`subcommands`]: crate::Command::subcommand()
2804    pub fn external_subcommand_value_parser(
2805        mut self,
2806        parser: impl IntoResettable<super::ValueParser>,
2807    ) -> Self {
2808        self.external_value_parser = parser.into_resettable().into_option();
2809        self
2810    }
2811
2812    /// Specifies that use of an argument prevents the use of [`subcommands`].
2813    ///
2814    /// By default `clap` allows arguments between subcommands such
2815    /// as `<cmd> [cmd_args] <subcmd> [subcmd_args] <subsubcmd> [subsubcmd_args]`.
2816    ///
2817    /// This setting disables that functionality and says that arguments can
2818    /// only follow the *final* subcommand. For instance using this setting
2819    /// makes only the following invocations possible:
2820    ///
2821    /// * `<cmd> <subcmd> <subsubcmd> [subsubcmd_args]`
2822    /// * `<cmd> <subcmd> [subcmd_args]`
2823    /// * `<cmd> [cmd_args]`
2824    ///
2825    /// # Examples
2826    ///
2827    /// ```rust
2828    /// # use clap::Command;
2829    /// Command::new("myprog")
2830    ///     .args_conflicts_with_subcommands(true);
2831    /// ```
2832    ///
2833    /// [`subcommands`]: crate::Command::subcommand()
2834    pub fn args_conflicts_with_subcommands(self, yes: bool) -> Self {
2835        if yes {
2836            self.setting(AppSettings::ArgsNegateSubcommands)
2837        } else {
2838            self.unset_setting(AppSettings::ArgsNegateSubcommands)
2839        }
2840    }
2841
2842    /// Prevent subcommands from being consumed as an arguments value.
2843    ///
2844    /// By default, if an option taking multiple values is followed by a subcommand, the
2845    /// subcommand will be parsed as another value.
2846    ///
2847    /// ```text
2848    /// cmd --foo val1 val2 subcommand
2849    ///           --------- ----------
2850    ///             values   another value
2851    /// ```
2852    ///
2853    /// This setting instructs the parser to stop when encountering a subcommand instead of
2854    /// greedily consuming arguments.
2855    ///
2856    /// ```text
2857    /// cmd --foo val1 val2 subcommand
2858    ///           --------- ----------
2859    ///             values   subcommand
2860    /// ```
2861    ///
2862    /// # Examples
2863    ///
2864    /// ```rust
2865    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, ArgAction};
2866    /// let cmd = Command::new("cmd").subcommand(Command::new("sub")).arg(
2867    ///     Arg::new("arg")
2868    ///         .long("arg")
2869    ///         .num_args(1..)
2870    ///         .action(ArgAction::Set),
2871    /// );
2872    ///
2873    /// let matches = cmd
2874    ///     .clone()
2875    ///     .try_get_matches_from(&["cmd", "--arg", "1", "2", "3", "sub"])
2876    ///     .unwrap();
2877    /// assert_eq!(
2878    ///     matches.get_many::<String>("arg").unwrap().collect::<Vec<_>>(),
2879    ///     &["1", "2", "3", "sub"]
2880    /// );
2881    /// assert!(matches.subcommand_matches("sub").is_none());
2882    ///
2883    /// let matches = cmd
2884    ///     .subcommand_precedence_over_arg(true)
2885    ///     .try_get_matches_from(&["cmd", "--arg", "1", "2", "3", "sub"])
2886    ///     .unwrap();
2887    /// assert_eq!(
2888    ///     matches.get_many::<String>("arg").unwrap().collect::<Vec<_>>(),
2889    ///     &["1", "2", "3"]
2890    /// );
2891    /// assert!(matches.subcommand_matches("sub").is_some());
2892    /// ```
2893    pub fn subcommand_precedence_over_arg(self, yes: bool) -> Self {
2894        if yes {
2895            self.setting(AppSettings::SubcommandPrecedenceOverArg)
2896        } else {
2897            self.unset_setting(AppSettings::SubcommandPrecedenceOverArg)
2898        }
2899    }
2900
2901    /// Allows [`subcommands`] to override all requirements of the parent command.
2902    ///
2903    /// For example, if you had a subcommand or top level application with a required argument
2904    /// that is only required as long as there is no subcommand present,
2905    /// using this setting would allow you to set those arguments to [`Arg::required(true)`]
2906    /// and yet receive no error so long as the user uses a valid subcommand instead.
2907    ///
2908    /// **NOTE:** This defaults to false (using subcommand does *not* negate requirements)
2909    ///
2910    /// # Examples
2911    ///
2912    /// This first example shows that it is an error to not use a required argument
2913    ///
2914    /// ```rust
2915    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, error::ErrorKind};
2916    /// let err = Command::new("myprog")
2917    ///     .subcommand_negates_reqs(true)
2918    ///     .arg(Arg::new("opt").required(true))
2919    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("test"))
2920    ///     .try_get_matches_from(vec![
2921    ///         "myprog"
2922    ///     ]);
2923    /// assert!(err.is_err());
2924    /// assert_eq!(err.unwrap_err().kind(), ErrorKind::MissingRequiredArgument);
2925    /// # ;
2926    /// ```
2927    ///
2928    /// This next example shows that it is no longer error to not use a required argument if a
2929    /// valid subcommand is used.
2930    ///
2931    /// ```rust
2932    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg, error::ErrorKind};
2933    /// let noerr = Command::new("myprog")
2934    ///     .subcommand_negates_reqs(true)
2935    ///     .arg(Arg::new("opt").required(true))
2936    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("test"))
2937    ///     .try_get_matches_from(vec![
2938    ///         "myprog", "test"
2939    ///     ]);
2940    /// assert!(noerr.is_ok());
2941    /// # ;
2942    /// ```
2943    ///
2944    /// [`Arg::required(true)`]: crate::Arg::required()
2945    /// [`subcommands`]: crate::Command::subcommand()
2946    pub fn subcommand_negates_reqs(self, yes: bool) -> Self {
2947        if yes {
2948            self.setting(AppSettings::SubcommandsNegateReqs)
2949        } else {
2950            self.unset_setting(AppSettings::SubcommandsNegateReqs)
2951        }
2952    }
2953
2954    /// Multiple-personality program dispatched on the binary name (`argv[0]`)
2955    ///
2956    /// A "multicall" executable is a single executable
2957    /// that contains a variety of applets,
2958    /// and decides which applet to run based on the name of the file.
2959    /// The executable can be called from different names by creating hard links
2960    /// or symbolic links to it.
2961    ///
2962    /// This is desirable for:
2963    /// - Easy distribution, a single binary that can install hardlinks to access the different
2964    ///   personalities.
2965    /// - Minimal binary size by sharing common code (e.g. standard library, clap)
2966    /// - Custom shells or REPLs where there isn't a single top-level command
2967    ///
2968    /// Setting `multicall` will cause
2969    /// - `argv[0]` to be stripped to the base name and parsed as the first argument, as if
2970    ///   [`Command::no_binary_name`][Command::no_binary_name] was set.
2971    /// - Help and errors to report subcommands as if they were the top-level command
2972    ///
2973    /// When the subcommand is not present, there are several strategies you may employ, depending
2974    /// on your needs:
2975    /// - Let the error percolate up normally
2976    /// - Print a specialized error message using the
2977    ///   [`Error::context`][crate::Error::context]
2978    /// - Print the [help][Command::write_help] but this might be ambiguous
2979    /// - Disable `multicall` and re-parse it
2980    /// - Disable `multicall` and re-parse it with a specific subcommand
2981    ///
2982    /// When detecting the error condition, the [`ErrorKind`] isn't sufficient as a sub-subcommand
2983    /// might report the same error.  Enable
2984    /// [`allow_external_subcommands`][Command::allow_external_subcommands] if you want to specifically
2985    /// get the unrecognized binary name.
2986    ///
2987    /// **NOTE:** Multicall can't be used with [`no_binary_name`] since they interpret
2988    /// the command name in incompatible ways.
2989    ///
2990    /// **NOTE:** The multicall command cannot have arguments.
2991    ///
2992    /// **NOTE:** Applets are slightly semantically different from subcommands,
2993    /// so it's recommended to use [`Command::subcommand_help_heading`] and
2994    /// [`Command::subcommand_value_name`] to change the descriptive text as above.
2995    ///
2996    /// # Examples
2997    ///
2998    /// `hostname` is an example of a multicall executable.
2999    /// Both `hostname` and `dnsdomainname` are provided by the same executable
3000    /// and which behaviour to use is based on the executable file name.
3001    ///
3002    /// This is desirable when the executable has a primary purpose
3003    /// but there is related functionality that would be convenient to provide
3004    /// and implement it to be in the same executable.
3005    ///
3006    /// The name of the cmd is essentially unused
3007    /// and may be the same as the name of a subcommand.
3008    ///
3009    /// The names of the immediate subcommands of the Command
3010    /// are matched against the basename of the first argument,
3011    /// which is conventionally the path of the executable.
3012    ///
3013    /// This does not allow the subcommand to be passed as the first non-path argument.
3014    ///
3015    /// ```rust
3016    /// # use clap::{Command, error::ErrorKind};
3017    /// let mut cmd = Command::new("hostname")
3018    ///     .multicall(true)
3019    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("hostname"))
3020    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("dnsdomainname"));
3021    /// let m = cmd.try_get_matches_from_mut(&["/usr/bin/hostname", "dnsdomainname"]);
3022    /// assert!(m.is_err());
3023    /// assert_eq!(m.unwrap_err().kind(), ErrorKind::UnknownArgument);
3024    /// let m = cmd.get_matches_from(&["/usr/bin/dnsdomainname"]);
3025    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("dnsdomainname"));
3026    /// ```
3027    ///
3028    /// Busybox is another common example of a multicall executable
3029    /// with a subcommmand for each applet that can be run directly,
3030    /// e.g. with the `cat` applet being run by running `busybox cat`,
3031    /// or with `cat` as a link to the `busybox` binary.
3032    ///
3033    /// This is desirable when the launcher program has additional options
3034    /// or it is useful to run the applet without installing a symlink
3035    /// e.g. to test the applet without installing it
3036    /// or there may already be a command of that name installed.
3037    ///
3038    /// To make an applet usable as both a multicall link and a subcommand
3039    /// the subcommands must be defined both in the top-level Command
3040    /// and as subcommands of the "main" applet.
3041    ///
3042    /// ```rust
3043    /// # use clap::Command;
3044    /// fn applet_commands() -> [Command; 2] {
3045    ///     [Command::new("true"), Command::new("false")]
3046    /// }
3047    /// let mut cmd = Command::new("busybox")
3048    ///     .multicall(true)
3049    ///     .subcommand(
3050    ///         Command::new("busybox")
3051    ///             .subcommand_value_name("APPLET")
3052    ///             .subcommand_help_heading("APPLETS")
3053    ///             .subcommands(applet_commands()),
3054    ///     )
3055    ///     .subcommands(applet_commands());
3056    /// // When called from the executable's canonical name
3057    /// // its applets can be matched as subcommands.
3058    /// let m = cmd.try_get_matches_from_mut(&["/usr/bin/busybox", "true"]).unwrap();
3059    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("busybox"));
3060    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand().unwrap().1.subcommand_name(), Some("true"));
3061    /// // When called from a link named after an applet that applet is matched.
3062    /// let m = cmd.get_matches_from(&["/usr/bin/true"]);
3063    /// assert_eq!(m.subcommand_name(), Some("true"));
3064    /// ```
3065    ///
3066    /// [`no_binary_name`]: crate::Command::no_binary_name
3067    /// [`Command::subcommand_value_name`]: crate::Command::subcommand_value_name
3068    /// [`Command::subcommand_help_heading`]: crate::Command::subcommand_help_heading
3069    #[inline]
3070    pub fn multicall(self, yes: bool) -> Self {
3071        if yes {
3072            self.setting(AppSettings::Multicall)
3073        } else {
3074            self.unset_setting(AppSettings::Multicall)
3075        }
3076    }
3077
3078    /// Sets the value name used for subcommands when printing usage and help.
3079    ///
3080    /// By default, this is "COMMAND".
3081    ///
3082    /// See also [`Command::subcommand_help_heading`]
3083    ///
3084    /// # Examples
3085    ///
3086    /// ```no_run
3087    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg};
3088    /// Command::new("myprog")
3089    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("sub1"))
3090    ///     .print_help()
3091    /// # ;
3092    /// ```
3093    ///
3094    /// will produce
3095    ///
3096    /// ```text
3097    /// myprog
3098    ///
3099    /// Usage: myprog [COMMAND]
3100    ///
3101    /// Commands:
3102    ///     help    Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)
3103    ///     sub1
3104    ///
3105    /// Options:
3106    ///     -h, --help       Print help information
3107    ///     -V, --version    Print version information
3108    /// ```
3109    ///
3110    /// but usage of `subcommand_value_name`
3111    ///
3112    /// ```no_run
3113    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg};
3114    /// Command::new("myprog")
3115    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("sub1"))
3116    ///     .subcommand_value_name("THING")
3117    ///     .print_help()
3118    /// # ;
3119    /// ```
3120    ///
3121    /// will produce
3122    ///
3123    /// ```text
3124    /// myprog
3125    ///
3126    /// Usage: myprog [THING]
3127    ///
3128    /// Commands:
3129    ///     help    Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)
3130    ///     sub1
3131    ///
3132    /// Options:
3133    ///     -h, --help       Print help information
3134    ///     -V, --version    Print version information
3135    /// ```
3136    #[must_use]
3137    pub fn subcommand_value_name(mut self, value_name: impl IntoResettable<Str>) -> Self {
3138        self.subcommand_value_name = value_name.into_resettable().into_option();
3139        self
3140    }
3141
3142    /// Sets the help heading used for subcommands when printing usage and help.
3143    ///
3144    /// By default, this is "Commands".
3145    ///
3146    /// See also [`Command::subcommand_value_name`]
3147    ///
3148    /// # Examples
3149    ///
3150    /// ```no_run
3151    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg};
3152    /// Command::new("myprog")
3153    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("sub1"))
3154    ///     .print_help()
3155    /// # ;
3156    /// ```
3157    ///
3158    /// will produce
3159    ///
3160    /// ```text
3161    /// myprog
3162    ///
3163    /// Usage: myprog [COMMAND]
3164    ///
3165    /// Commands:
3166    ///     help    Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)
3167    ///     sub1
3168    ///
3169    /// Options:
3170    ///     -h, --help       Print help information
3171    ///     -V, --version    Print version information
3172    /// ```
3173    ///
3174    /// but usage of `subcommand_help_heading`
3175    ///
3176    /// ```no_run
3177    /// # use clap::{Command, Arg};
3178    /// Command::new("myprog")
3179    ///     .subcommand(Command::new("sub1"))
3180    ///     .subcommand_help_heading("Things")
3181    ///     .print_help()
3182    /// # ;
3183    /// ```
3184    ///
3185    /// will produce
3186    ///
3187    /// ```text
3188    /// myprog
3189    ///
3190    /// Usage: myprog [COMMAND]
3191    ///
3192    /// Things:
3193    ///     help    Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)
3194    ///     sub1
3195    ///
3196    /// Options:
3197    ///     -h, --help       Print help information
3198    ///     -V, --version    Print version information
3199    /// ```
3200    #[must_use]
3201    pub fn subcommand_help_heading(mut self, heading: impl IntoResettable<Str>) -> Self {
3202        self.subcommand_heading = heading.into_resettable().into_option();
3203        self
3204    }
3205}

3348    /// Should we color the output?
3349    pub fn get_color(&self) -> ColorChoice {
3350        debug!("Command::color: Color setting...");
3351
3352        if cfg!(feature = "color") {
3353            if self.is_set(AppSettings::ColorNever) {
3354                debug!("Never");
3355                ColorChoice::Never
3356            } else if self.is_set(AppSettings::ColorAlways) {
3357                debug!("Always");
3358                ColorChoice::Always
3359            } else {
3360                debug!("Auto");
3361                ColorChoice::Auto
3362            }
3363        } else {
3364            ColorChoice::Never
3365        }
3366    }

3422    /// Find subcommand such that its name or one of aliases equals `name`.
3423    ///
3424    /// This does not recurse through subcommands of subcommands.
3425    #[inline]
3426    pub fn find_subcommand(&self, name: impl AsRef<std::ffi::OsStr>) -> Option<&Command> {
3427        let name = name.as_ref();
3428        self.get_subcommands().find(|s| s.aliases_to(name))
3429    }

3432    /// a mutable reference to the subcommand.
3433    ///
3434    /// This does not recurse through subcommands of subcommands.
3435    #[inline]
3436    pub fn find_subcommand_mut(
3437        &mut self,
3438        name: impl AsRef<std::ffi::OsStr>,
3439    ) -> Option<&mut Command> {
3440        let name = name.as_ref();
3441        self.get_subcommands_mut().find(|s| s.aliases_to(name))
3442    }

3466    }

3468    /// Get a list of all arguments the given argument conflicts with.
3469    ///
3470    /// If the provided argument is declared as global, the conflicts will be determined
3471    /// based on the propagation rules of global arguments.
3472    ///
3473    /// ### Panics
3474    ///
3475    /// If the given arg contains a conflict with an argument that is unknown to
3476    /// this `Command`.
3477    pub fn get_arg_conflicts_with(&self, arg: &Arg) -> Vec<&Arg> // FIXME: This could probably have been an iterator
3478    {
3479        if arg.is_global_set() {
3480            self.get_global_arg_conflicts_with(arg)
3481        } else {
3482            let mut result = Vec::new();
3483            for id in arg.blacklist.iter() {
3484                if let Some(arg) = self.find(id) {
3485                    result.push(arg);
3486                } else if let Some(group) = self.find_group(id) {
3487                    result.extend(
3488                        self.unroll_args_in_group(&group.id)
3489                            .iter()
3490                            .map(|id| self.find(id).expect(INTERNAL_ERROR_MSG)),
3491                    );
3492                } else {
3493                    panic!("Command::get_arg_conflicts_with: The passed arg conflicts with an arg unknown to the cmd");
3494                }
3495            }
3496            result
3497        }
3498    }
3499
3500    // Get a unique list of all arguments of all commands and continuous subcommands the given argument conflicts with.
3501    //
3502    // This behavior follows the propagation rules of global arguments.
3503    // It is useful for finding conflicts for arguments declared as global.
3504    //
3505    // ### Panics
3506    //
3507    // If the given arg contains a conflict with an argument that is unknown to
3508    // this `Command`.
3509    fn get_global_arg_conflicts_with(&self, arg: &Arg) -> Vec<&Arg> // FIXME: This could probably have been an iterator
3510    {
3511        arg.blacklist
3512            .iter()
3513            .map(|id| {
3514                self.args
3515                    .args()
3516                    .chain(
3517                        self.get_subcommands_containing(arg)
3518                            .iter()
3519                            .flat_map(|x| x.args.args()),
3520                    )
3521                    .find(|arg| arg.get_id() == id)
3522                    .expect(
3523                        "Command::get_arg_conflicts_with: \
3524                    The passed arg conflicts with an arg unknown to the cmd",
3525                    )
3526            })
3527            .collect()
3528    }
3529
3530    // Get a list of subcommands which contain the provided Argument
3531    //
3532    // This command will only include subcommands in its list for which the subcommands
3533    // parent also contains the Argument.
3534    //
3535    // This search follows the propagation rules of global arguments.
3536    // It is useful to finding subcommands, that have inherited a global argument.
3537    //
3538    // **NOTE:** In this case only Sucommand_1 will be included
3539    //   Subcommand_1 (contains Arg)
3540    //     Subcommand_1.1 (doesn't contain Arg)
3541    //       Subcommand_1.1.1 (contains Arg)
3542    //
3543    fn get_subcommands_containing(&self, arg: &Arg) -> Vec<&Self> {
3544        let mut vec = std::vec::Vec::new();
3545        for idx in 0..self.subcommands.len() {
3546            if self.subcommands[idx]
3547                .args
3548                .args()
3549                .any(|ar| ar.get_id() == arg.get_id())
3550            {
3551                vec.push(&self.subcommands[idx]);
3552                vec.append(&mut self.subcommands[idx].get_subcommands_containing(arg));
3553            }
3554        }
3555        vec
3556    }

3658    #[doc(hidden)]
3659    #[cfg_attr(
3660        feature = "deprecated",
3661        deprecated(since = "4.0.0", note = "Replaced with `Arg::is_trailing_var_arg_set`")
3662    )]
3663    pub fn is_trailing_var_arg_set(&self) -> bool {
3664        self.is_set(AppSettings::TrailingVarArg)
3665    }
3666
3667    /// Report whether [`Command::allow_missing_positional`] is set
3668    pub fn is_allow_missing_positional_set(&self) -> bool {
3669        self.is_set(AppSettings::AllowMissingPositional)
3670    }
3671
3672    /// Report whether [`Command::hide`] is set
3673    pub fn is_hide_set(&self) -> bool {
3674        self.is_set(AppSettings::Hidden)
3675    }
3676
3677    /// Report whether [`Command::subcommand_required`] is set
3678    pub fn is_subcommand_required_set(&self) -> bool {
3679        self.is_set(AppSettings::SubcommandRequired)
3680    }
3681
3682    /// Report whether [`Command::allow_external_subcommands`] is set
3683    pub fn is_allow_external_subcommands_set(&self) -> bool {
3684        self.is_set(AppSettings::AllowExternalSubcommands)
3685    }
3686
3687    /// Configured parser for values passed to an external subcommand
3688    ///
3689    /// # Example
3690    ///
3691    /// ```rust
3692    /// let cmd = clap::Command::new("raw")
3693    ///     .external_subcommand_value_parser(clap::value_parser!(String));
3694    /// let value_parser = cmd.get_external_subcommand_value_parser();
3695    /// println!("{:?}", value_parser);
3696    /// ```
3697    pub fn get_external_subcommand_value_parser(&self) -> Option<&super::ValueParser> {
3698        if !self.is_allow_external_subcommands_set() {
3699            None
3700        } else {
3701            static DEFAULT: super::ValueParser = super::ValueParser::os_string();
3702            Some(self.external_value_parser.as_ref().unwrap_or(&DEFAULT))
3703        }
3704    }
3705
3706    /// Report whether [`Command::args_conflicts_with_subcommands`] is set
3707    pub fn is_args_conflicts_with_subcommands_set(&self) -> bool {
3708        self.is_set(AppSettings::ArgsNegateSubcommands)
3709    }
3710
3711    #[doc(hidden)]
3712    pub fn is_args_override_self(&self) -> bool {
3713        self.is_set(AppSettings::AllArgsOverrideSelf)
3714    }
3715
3716    /// Report whether [`Command::subcommand_precedence_over_arg`] is set
3717    pub fn is_subcommand_precedence_over_arg_set(&self) -> bool {
3718        self.is_set(AppSettings::SubcommandPrecedenceOverArg)
3719    }
3720
3721    /// Report whether [`Command::subcommand_negates_reqs`] is set
3722    pub fn is_subcommand_negates_reqs_set(&self) -> bool {
3723        self.is_set(AppSettings::SubcommandsNegateReqs)
3724    }
3725
3726    /// Report whether [`Command::multicall`] is set
3727    pub fn is_multicall_set(&self) -> bool {
3728        self.is_set(AppSettings::Multicall)
3729    }
3730}
